transcription.text: Like Thor, Tessa Thompson’s King Valkyrie had plenty of costume changes throughout Thor: Love and Thunder. Her hero armour has been adapted to fit the bolder, more 80s look of the latest film, with stark, armoured panels of black and white. Thompson loved the variety of looks for Valkyrie. “I love a costume change,” she said. “You get to see Valkyrie in these suited kingly looks, and then you get to see her in her pyjamas, which I love. Because when have you ever seen a superhero in pyjamas? Even heroes go to sleep.” She continued: “I think that’s what’s really exciting about these films, in general, is to see the way in which characters evolve.”

work.title: Valkyrie costume with sword, sheath and daggers

transcription.text: Footage captured during war has the ability to give audiences a sense of what is happening in combat, documenting the frontlines with an unflinching lens and bearing witness to atrocities. Yet it can also be used as propaganda to enlist forces, making it a powerful tool. Eastman Kodak introduced the Ciné-Kodak Special in 1933 following on from its earlier model the Ciné-Kodak in 1923. The silent 16mm camera was durable and lightweight enough to be used by combat photographers working in the field and Kodak manufactured a military version in all-black without the usual chrome edges.
This partially assembled camera shows the many tightly packed components, including thermal management, circuit boards, microphones, image sensor and light filters hidden inside the camera’s body.

work.title: URSA Mini Pro 4.6K G2 Partial Assembly

transcription.text:
The chassis is the main structural element of the camera, and is die-cast with a magnesium alloy that is very light and strong.

The image sensor assembly with its large liquid cooled radiator is shown here mounted to the front of the chassis.

work.title: URSA Mini Pro 4.6K G2 Image Sensor Assembly and Chassis

transcription.text: This prototype was built using a combination of stereolithography (SLA) and full colour 3D printed parts, which were made from a powdered material solidified by an inkjet printing process over hundreds of layers. It was used by the Blackmagic Industrial Design team during the early stages of design process to evaluate the camera's design and functionality.

work.title: URSA Mini Pro 4.6K G2 Form Prototype

transcription.text: Around 2015, Emmy Award-winning filmmaker Jody Eldred tested a pre-production model of the BlackMagic URSA Mini 4.6K in the Las Vegas desert. Aside from his 40-year career in film and TV, Eldred had spent 15 years testing cameras. “Wow,” was his response to the camera’s quality, but he had a few suggestions for on how to improve it. Less than a year later the URSA Mini Pro 4.6k was released with those changes implemented. “I was stunned,” Eldred has said. He hadn’t encountered a camera company that listened to the people who use them.

URSA Mini Pro is a professional digital film camera that combines high resolution
image quality with the features and controls of a traditional broadcast camera.
A highly versatile camera format, it’s been used in the creation of a number of
Hollywood productions, television and streaming series as well as studio and
live production events.

Illustrators toying with perspective surprised and delighted people when they produced seemingly ordinary illustrations that revealed hidden images depending on how you look at them. Upside down heads, which date back to around the 1700s, were one of the most popular Victorian era optical illusions, featuring on playing cards, match boxes, puzzles and in newspapers, where peacocks morphed into bearded men and royalty turned into skeletons.

Not all domestic narratives are told best in words. Witch Beam Games’ award-winning Unpacking (2021) is a domestic game where players get to know the unseen protagonist not by listening to her speak or meeting her on-screen, but by unpacking her house each time she moves. The demo you can play here depicts the first room, her childhood bedroom, which lays the foundation for her values and interests. In each new house, the player can choose where to put the toys, mementos and furniture that come out of each moving box – but you have no control over what she chooses to pack. Each new moving box reveals more about the character as she grows up. Through this immersive story, you develop a deeper understanding of her values, giving us a clear portrait of the character not by being told, but by experiencing her relationship with domestic space.
